node.title: Russian military warns debris from one of its rockets could fall into Tasmanian waters
node.alt: A rocket blasts off at night, sending engine exhust over the launch pad.
node.description: A blunt warning from the Russian military that rocket debris may fall close to Tasmania came as quite the surprise to the island's aviation industry, with one pilot saying it made a change from the usual messages aboutÂ "boring things, like the runway is closed because it's wet".
node.content:
["A warning was sent today that debris from a Russian military rocket launch may pepper the icy waters off southern Tasmania, but it is likely only fish will have seen anything.", "International authorities issued what is known as\u00a0a NOTAM \u2014 a notice to airmen \u2014 warning that debris could fall across a region stretching from about 100 kilometres south of Tasmania to many hundreds of kilometres to the south-east.", "The NASA Spaceflight website, which covers launches, said the Soyuz rocket was carrying an \"early warning\" satellite for the Russian military, part of a network of satellites said to warn of ballistic missile attacks against Russia.", "It said the rocket was\u00a0launched at 12:09pm AEDT from the\u00a0Plesetsk Cosmodrome, about 800km\u00a0north of Moscow.", "Shannon Wells, the owner of Hobart flight training\u00a0company Par Avion, said it was the first time he had\u00a0ever seen a NOTAM of its kind.", "\"We're used to seeing boring things, like the runway is closed because it's wet or a navigation beacon is broken,\" he said.", "University of Tasmania physics professor Simon Ellingsen said the debris warning included an area 162km\u00a0from Hobart, or about 100km from the southern tip of Tasmania.", "\"There is a chance that some of that debris will [have] come down quite close to Tasmania, but it's likely to be well into the Southern Ocean,\" he said.", "\"There'll be quite a few people monitoring it, mainly military. I'm sure the Australian military will be watching.\"", "", "
The locations marked on the NOTAM as possible sites for debris.(Supplied: GCMap)
", "He said the debris would be either the first or second stage of the Soyuz 2.1b launch vehicle.", "\"Each of those first two stages burn for about five\u00a0minutes and then are jettisoned and fall back to Earth over a similar period of time,\" he said.", "
Similar to debris seen last year
", "", "
Space debris that is thought to have come from a Russian rocket launch was visible in Devonport in May 2020.(Supplied: Luka van de Wolfshaar)
", "Professor Ellingsen said it was the same type of rocket from the same launch location as the one that may have caused a fireball over Victorian and Tasmanian skies in May 2020.", "This type of space junk will become easier to detect in future with the University of Tasmania signing a Memorandum of Understanding with the newly formed Australian Space Agency in July.", "", "
A strange fireball was seen over central Victoria during the May 2020 event.
", "A new antennae is being built at the University's Greenhill Observatory and is expected to start operating next year.", "\"One activity it'll be used for is as a bistatic radar and that will allow us to actively track things like space debris,\" Professor Ellingsen said.", "A Civil Aviation Safety Authority spokesman said the debris would have only posed a risk if it fell over a commercial flight path and no commercial planes fly that far south."]
